guide.introduction: This guide provides a step-by-step process for building a self-guided golf club carrier using an Arduino, sensors, and a kid's electric car.
guide.introduction_rendered:
This guide provides a step-by-step process for building a self-guided golf club carrier using an Arduino, sensors, and a kid's electric car.

Relevant parts
  • Arduino Uno
  • IR Beacon Transceiver
  • Kids Electric Car
  • Motor Shield Kit
  • Scrap Material such as Plastic or Lumber
  • Pivot Wheel
Tools
  • Computer
  • Jigsaw
  • Soldering iron

parts.text: Scrap Material such as Plastic or Lumber

steps.title: Disassembly of Kid's Electric Car: Motors

lines.text: Take a Phillips screwdriver and remove the back purple frame. Take one screw out of the back of the seat to reach the motors.
lines.text_raw: Take a Phillips screwdriver and remove the back purple frame. Take one screw out of the back of the seat to reach the motors.

lines.text: After unhinging the seat, two motors connected to a switch can be found underneath. The switch controls the speed of the toy car.
lines.text_raw: After unhinging the seat, two motors connected to a switch can be found underneath. The switch controls the speed of the toy car.

lines.text: Take apart the back axle and wheels to remove the motors from the car.
lines.text_raw: Take apart the back axle and wheels to remove the motors from the car.

lines.text: Open up the floor of the car to reveal the wire connecting the battery and pedal to the motors.
lines.text_raw: Open up the floor of the car to reveal the wire connecting the battery and pedal to the motors.

lines.text: Unscrew the hood of the car and slip the battery wire through to the backside, where the motors are.
lines.text_raw: Unscrew the hood of the car and slip the battery wire through to the backside, where the motors are.

lines.text: The final disassembly should include the two motors, speed control, battery connector, and the go switch all connected to each other.
lines.text_raw: The final disassembly should include the two motors, speed control, battery connector, and the go switch all connected to each other.

lines.text: Using a jigsaw, remove the front half of the vehicle as shown in the third picture for this step.
lines.text_raw: Using a jigsaw, remove the front half of the vehicle as shown in the third picture for this step.

lines.text: Use the diagrams provided by the sensor manufacturer to properly place the electrical components on the sensor board.
lines.text_raw: Use the diagrams provided by the sensor manufacturer to properly place the electrical components on the sensor board.

lines.text: Use the medium heat setting on the soldering gun to melt down the solder to secure the components.
lines.text_raw: Use the medium heat setting on the soldering gun to melt down the solder to secure the components.

steps.title: Obtain Arduino Code and Program Arduino

lines.text: After purchasing the Arduino, download the free Arduino software to your computer from http://www.arduino.cc/
lines.text_raw: After purchasing the Arduino, download the free Arduino software to your computer from http://www.arduino.cc/

lines.text: Attach the Arduino to your computer using the USB connector included in the starter kit. Program the Arduino using the Arduino code found here.
lines.text_raw: Attach the Arduino to your computer using the USB connector included in the starter kit. Program the Arduino using the Arduino code found [http://www.robotishappy.com/2009/12/beacon-locating-robot-powered-by-arduino-and-ir-transceiver/|here].

steps.title: Integration of Motors and Sensors with Ardiuno

lines.text: This website provides details for attaching the sensors, microcontroller and motors.
lines.text_raw: [https://github.com/chazlett/beacon_locating_robot|This website] provides details for attaching the sensors, microcontroller and motors.

lines.text: Use the back half of the kid's car and some scrap material (such as lumber or plastic if it's available) to create a support frame for the front end of the carrier.
lines.text_raw: Use the back half of the kid's car and some scrap material (such as lumber or plastic if it's available) to create a support frame for the front end of the carrier.

lines.text: Secure the material to the kid's car with bolts and screws and build outward to produce a frame. Bringing the front end to a point is suggested because it will allow for a single pivot wheel and it will provide a strong structure.
lines.text_raw: Secure the material to the kid's car with bolts and screws and build outward to produce a frame. Bringing the front end to a point is suggested because it will allow for a single pivot wheel and it will provide a strong structure.

lines.text: Attach a pivot wheel at the front end of your newly created structure.
lines.text_raw: Attach a pivot wheel at the front end of your newly created structure.
